Yeah, but it won't be worth your time. Remember that even if you totally kill the markets and get a 20% return, that's just 20 bucks in actual profit. Your *time* is probably better spent doing something else.

Yep, this happens all the time. A few thoughts:
1. It's good practice to write this stuff yourself, so you know how it works! 2. This kind of mishap (trying to reinvent the wheel) will slow you down greatly at work. Beware. Hand-rolling your own libraries takes forever, and chances are that other tools are better-developed. 3. Consequently, it's a good idea to do your research thoroughly before starting. Not just so you can find tools that you can use instead of needing to write them yourself, but also so you can *understand* pitfalls and limitations of approaches, should you choose to write a custom tool.

We use "less" for continuous quantities, and "fewer" for discrete quantities. This distinction between continuous and discrete is valuable, and subverting it sacrifices clarity. You can, of course, subvert it because there's no central authority to tell you off, but you're ultimately just making it harder for others to parse your statements.

Shoot, I think you're right! I looked into cProfile in more detail just now. I didn't realize you could just use it on `main` and have it profile all included functions. Well, I learned something today.

cProfile is mostly for profiling test cases; it does not provide on-the-fly profiling while running your program in production.
For example, suppose you're running a Python backend on a server, and you're noticing performance issues at times, but your codebase is so large that you're not sure where the performance issues are originating. This tool will help you find the functions calls that are taking too long.

WRITING.TITLE: Function-Profiler: Module to Profile Function Performance in Production

WRITING.TEXT:
I needed to profile some function calls in a production setting, so I wrote this module to record counts of function calls, as well as their execution times. I'm hoping that you might find it useful!
I'm also looking for some feedback: for example, whether there are any useful features that I could add. Maybe I could add a warning if function calls start taking too much time? I am interested in your opinions.

WRITING.TITLE: A Small Module to Profile Function Performance

WRITING.TEXT: I was opening this thread hoping to make a snide joke about the rent being a *modest billion dollars* per month; but it appears that I've been beaten by four hours to the joke, and by a factor of about 6.02 x 10^14 to a realistic pricing estimate.

I don't mean to be the guy pedantically correcting spelling or whatever, but I just wanted to point out that it's a *prix-fixe* meal (French for *fixed price*), not a *pre-fixed* meal. (What would a "pre-fixed" meal actually be?) The pronunciation is almost the same, minus a *d*, so it's easy to slip up.

Exactly. This was my thinking as well. I have no intention to share solutions to the harder problems (100+).

I know. I disagree with this position. Here's a summary of my views:
- Project Euler problems provide some internal value to the solver. The feeling of reward from solving a PE problem is not diminished by existing solutions. If you want to solve the problems fair-and-square, don't look at the solutions.
- Project Euler problems provide external value to the solver, i.e. the solver is able to say "I solved these problems" and use that as a credential. I think this is a minor benefit that is strongly outweighed by the educational usefulness of having solutions freely available, both for people who have and have not solved the problems.

WRITING.TITLE: [P] Intro to K-Means Clustering, Implementation of Lloyd's Algorithm
Solutions to the First 50 Problems in Python 3.6
